div.p:
It is doubtless known to most of our citi-
zens that for a few years past, Prof. Lorin
Blodget, formerly of this County, has been
engaged in prosecuting important scientific
labors in Washington: but we presume few
of them have been acquainted with the
difficulties he has encountered, nor the high
position, in spite of them, to which he has
attained. When Prof. B. went to Washin-
gton, five or six years since, he was entrusted
with the Meetorological Meteorological Department in the
Smithsonian Institute. At that time, the
results of meteorological observations taken
at the several military posts during more
than a quarter of a century, and at other
points by State direction and reported to the
institute, were a mere mass of rubbish, un-
compiled unclassified, and, for all purposes of
practical use worthless. He completed the
labor of systemizing them: and after having
thus brought order out of confusion, and
preparded prepared a valuable work upon American
climatology, the first contribution of the kind
in the country, certain aristocratic old fogies
connected with the Institution, who had
made their places mere sinecures, attempted
to rob him of the fruits of his hard-earned
honors. He resisted their pretensions, fought
them single-handed, and whatever he has
since accomplished, has been in the face of a
persecution that knew no honor nor merey.
He has, however, published his work, and
now has the proud satisfaction of receiving
from Baron Von Humboldt the following
tribute to the value of his labor. The com-
pliment is the more marked, because, from
his great age and demands upon his time
the Baron rarely indites such epistles himself
and this one, delivered to Prof. Blodget by
the Prussian Minister in person, is all of it
in Humboldt’s own hand writing:

Sir: I am very sensible of the honor
you have done me in communicating your
important work on the Distribusion of
Heat over the vast area of the United
States.

When I returned from my Expedition to
the North of Asia, near the close of 1829, I
proposed to the Academy of St. Petersburgh
to establish Meteorological Observations at
Moscow, Pekin, Archangel, and in the Cau-
casus; and referred at length to what had
been done in your noble country since 1822
under care of Messrs. Lovell and Lawson
at a large number of military posts near its
extreme limits.

The work to which you have devoted
yourself with so much care and intelligence,
is a most meritorious one—the graphic
representation of Climates by the isothermal
lines. For it I beg you to accept the expres-
sion of my lively gratitude.

As it is possible that you may not have re-
ceived a very recent memoir by M. Dove,
my fellow member of the Academy of Ber-
lin, 1 take the liberty to offer it to you. The
memoir is printed in the Journal of the Geo-
graphical Society of Berlin, for June, 1866
and you will find in it many points for further
comparison.

I renew, my dear sir, the assurance of the
high consideration with which I have the
honor to be

closer.salute:
Yours very obedient
And very humble Servant,
A. V. Humboldt.
